section.title: Introduction
section.para: Automated testing Continuous Integration without automated testing isn't really Continuous Integration - it's simply a small improvement on automatically scheduled builds. Indeed, if you are using Hudson without any automated tests, you are not getting anywhere near as much value out of your Continuous Integration infrastructure as you should.

One of the fundamental tenants of Continuous Integration is that a build should be verifiable. It must be possible to objectively determine whether a particular build artifact is ready to proceed to the next stage of the build process, and the most convenient way to do this is by using automated tests. Without proper automated testing set up in your build process, you will find yourself having to retain many build artifacts and test them by hand, which is hardly in the spirit of Continuous Integration.
In this chapter, we will see how Hudson helps you keep track of automated test results, and how you can use this information to monitor and dissect your build process.

section.title: Integrating JUnit test results
section.para: JUnit is the de facto standard of the Java world in unit testing tools.
Hudson understands the JUnit test report format, and does an excellent job of displaying JUnit test results (see ).
